resources.text: Classes have been mentioned many times in the previous courses. It's time to explain what they are, and how they can be created.
resources.boxed: Object oriented programming (OOP) has 3 basic principles. These are encapsulation, inheritance and polymorphism. In the following chapters it'll be explained what these terms mean and how they are implemented in Java.
resources.text:
A class is an abstract data type, but it's more then just a bundle of primitive types. We can also define behaviour for it by creating methods.

The class defines the structure. It's a blueprint for objects.

An object is what we get when a class is instantiated. Let's demonstrate this with an example project:
resources.boxed:
Create a project, and add a class which has the main method (This is what we've been doing so far). Then, add another class in the same package. This abstract data type will represent cats, because everyone likes cats. Name the class Cat.

See the code samples and instructions below for details!
resources.text: Your Main class should look something like this:
resources.code:
package oop;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {

    }

}
resources.text: Create the Cat class. In Eclipse this can be done by right clicking your package, then New > Class. This will create a file called Cat.java, and write the skeleton of the class for us:
Remember that we are now creating the abstract type cat! Let's encode the following information in our data type ( these are called members of the class):
resources.list:
• Name: stored in a String.
  • Age: stored in an int.
  • Gender: we can use a boolean, since each cat is either male or female.
resources.text: Here is our class after we include these members. As you can see, it's like local variable declaration, but in this case these are written outside methods, but inside the class.
resources.code:
package oop;

public class Cat {
    
    String name;
    
    int age;
    
    //if it's true the cat is male, otherwise it's female.
    boolean isMale;

}
resources.text: Let's also add some behaviour to this cat class using methods. One method will print the properties of the cat to the console, the other will calculate and return it's birth year.
resources.code:
package oop;

import java.time.Year;

public class Cat {
    
    String name;
    
    int age;
    
    //if it's true the cat is male, otherwise it's female.
    boolean isMale;

    int getBirthYear() {
         int currentYear = Year.now().getValue();
         return currentYear - age;
    }
    
    void printCatProperties() {
         System.out.println("Name: " + name);
         System.out.println("Age: " + age);
         if(isMale) {
              System.out.println("This cat is a male.");
         } else {
              System.out.println("This cat is a female.");
         }
    }
}
resources.boxed:
Those who did the tasks of the previous course are already familiar with this, but for those who did not, here it is again:

The Year.now().getValue() returns the current year as an integer. This is a better way then 'hardcoding' the year into our code.
resources.text: Now that we have the 'blueprint' (class) for cats, we can create actual cat objects in our program! For this, we'll use the main method:
resources.code:
package oop;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
         //create a cat and set its members
         Cat cat1 = new Cat();
         cat1.name = "Cirmi";
         cat1.age = 13;
         cat1.isMale = true;
         
         //create another cat, also set members
         Cat cat2 = new Cat();
         cat2.name = "Murci";
         cat2.age = 11;
         cat2.isMale = true;
         
         //print information about cat1
         cat1.printCatProperties();
         
         //get the birth year of cat2
         System.out.println("\nCat2 (" + cat2.name + ") was born in " + cat2.getBirthYear());
    }
}
resources.text: Notice that the objects are created using the new keyword.
resources.boxed: As you can see in this example, to reference the member variables and methods of an object, the dot operator can be used.
resources.advanced: When creating the object all members are set to their default values. For example, if we didn't explicitly give a name to the cat, it would be null. If we didn't initialize the age, it would be 0.
resources.text:
Each object has an identity. This means that even if they are of the same class and all their members are equal, that still does not mean they themselves are equal!

This code sample demonstrates this:
resources.code:
//create a cat and set its members
Cat cat1 = new Cat();
cat1.name = "Cirmi";
cat1.age = 13;
cat1.isMale = true;

//create another cat, all members are equal
Cat cat2 = new Cat();
cat2.name = "Cirmi";
cat2.age = 13;
cat2.isMale = true;

if(cat1 == cat2) {
    System.out.println("The cats are equal!");
} else {
    //this will be printed
    System.out.println("The cats are NOT equal!");
}
resources.text: This isn't very intuitive in most cases, we want to have a way to check 'equality' between our objects. As this example demonstrates, the == operator won't work. Java offers a solution, and it's called the equals method. More on this when we've already learned about inheritance and method overwriting.

The this keyword is used to reference the current object in the methods of the class. If that sounds confusing, don't worry. Here are some examples of it's usage that should clear it up:

Suppose we need a method for our Cat class that increases the age of the cat by one, then returns the Cat object.

Without the this keyword, we wouldn't have any way of referencing the current cat object!

For the next example, we need a method that updates the value of the cats name, and for the sake of clarity the parameter of this method is also called name, just like the member variable.

this will now be used to remove the ambiguity of the variable name!
resources.code:
void setName(String name) {
    /*
    When we write 'name' here, it'll mean the parameter, and not the
    member variable! To reference the member, the this keyword can be used.
     */
    this.name = name;
}
resources.text: These types of methods that update member values are called setters. You can see that the naming of the method reflects this.
